body: Charles R. Drew University is established in South Los Angeles.
title: Founding

body: Drew signs its first contract with L.A. County to provide health care and education services at Martin Luther King, Jr. Community Hospital, which officially opens the following year in South L.A. to provide care for a significantly underserved community.
title: Drew and King unite

body: Nine-year-old Dunia Tasejo is struck by a car and rushed to King/Drew Medical Center. According to a Los Angeles Times investigation, health providers at the hospital pumped her body with enough drugs to sedate a grown man, then hooked up to ventilator that wasn't set correctly. She was taken off the machine prematurely, and then for the next two hours, remained unmonitored by nurses. She eventually went brain-dead and, after two days, was taken off life support and died.
title: Dunia Tasejo

body: Drew announces that it will close its residency program at King Hospital, due its inability to secure long-term financial stability or accreditation.
title: Drew shuts down residency program

body: Edith Rodriguez, 43, dies of a perforated bowel at King/Drew after bleeding its emergency room floor for 45 minutes. As Rodriguez writhed in pain, hospital workers refused to take her in, leaving her in the waiting area. The infamous incident provided L.A. County supervisors with a devastating portrait of the facility's quality of care.
title: Edith Rodriguez

body: Despite a last-ditch attempt by UCLA to save it, inpatient services at King Hospital are shut down by L.A. County Supervisors amid accusations of gross negligence. Outpatient and urgent care services continue to operate at the hospital's former site in the MLK, Jr. Multi-Service Ambulatory Care Center.
title: King shuttered

body: Drew announces a new, $43-million nursing program.
title: Shaky investment

body: The accrediting commission of the Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC) upholds Drew's accreditation, but puts the university on probation, citing, for one, "the need for improvement in the systems of documentation, educational assessment and quality control."
title: Drew on probation

body: The California Endowment makes a floundering Drew an offer it can't refuse: If the school's board and president resigned, the Endowment promised to use its reputation and money help the school stabilize its situation. Drew accepts the offer.
title: Turning point

body: Drew is removed from academic probation by WASC and regains full accreditation; Dr. David Carlisle takes over as president.
title: Rebirth

body: Drew receives a $25-million grant for research, indicating that its turnaround is picking up momentum.
title: Cause for optimism

body: The new King Hospital is scheduled to open. Whether Drew will resume its role as a feeder school for a King residency program remains to be seen.
title: The new King
